description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Insatsen gäller stöd om 92 000 000 SEK till den andra fasen av Joint UN Programme on Social Protection under åren 2019 - 2022. Avtalspart är UNICEF och medverkande FN-organisationer är WFP och ILO. Den första fasen genomfördes mellan 2016 och 2019 och fick stöd av Finland, Irland, UK samt Sverige. Fortsättningen bygger vidare på resultat och erfarenheter från den första fasen och har ett något snävare fokus på i första hand att bygga system och kapacitet kring socialbidragssystemet för de allra fattigaste i Zambia. Ytterligare viktiga komponenter är integrering av jämställdhet, anpassning för funktionshindrade, förbättrad nutrition för gravida och ammande kvinnor samt system för ökade utvecklingseffekter genom förbättrade länkar mellan socialbidrag och andra insatser sk Cash+. En ytterligare komponent gäller utbetalning av extra socialbidrag under 2019, 2020 och 2021 till mottagare i distrikt som är särskilt drabbade av torka och Covid 19. Programmets ska finansieras gemensamt av Sverige och UK.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Support to the second phase of the Joint UN Programme on Social Protection 2019-2022. Agreement partner is UNICEF and the participating UN Organisations are WFP and ILO. The first phase was implemented between 2016 and 2019 and was supported by Finland, Ireland, UK and Sweden. The continuation builds upon the results and lessons learned in the first phase but is more focused on building systems and capacity around the social cash transfers for the poorest in Zambia. Other important Components of the programme are mainstreaming of gender and disability, improved nutrition for pregnant and lactating mothers as well as increased development effects through enhanced operational links between social cash transfers and other initiatives, so called cash+. An additional component deals with Emergecy Cash Transfers during 2019, 2020 and 2021 to households that are hardest hit by the prolonged reduced rainfalls as well as Covid 19. The programme is to be funded by Sweden and UK.

The Joint UN Programme on Social Protection phase II has the following expected results: Impact: Reduced Multi-dimentional poverty Outcomes: 1. Predictable and regular Social Cash Transfers 2. Operational Cash+ linkages 3. Improved nutrition 4. Disability mainstreaming 5. Improved cluster perfomace In addition the programme has a component of Emergency Cash Transfers with payments during 2019 and 2020 to social cash beneficiaries in the districts hardest hit by the prolonged reduced rainfall. In 2020 another round of Emergency Cash Transfers has been added to mitigate the situation related to covid-19. Sida plan to contribute financially to the covid-19 ECT through an amendment to the programme agreement.

description.narrative: Three core systems pilots for the Social Cash Transfers (SCT) were concluded in readiness for scale-up to all districts in 2021. The SCT grievance mechanism pilot was concluded, serving as a blueprint of the mechanism which is being rolled out to 67 additional districts. An integrated payment service delivery system was launched and operationalised in 17 pilot districts under the Zambia Integrated Social Protection Information Systems (ZISPIS) pilot. Efforts to strengthen financial management concluded with the piloting of the financial management system - Navision in 12 pilot districts in Central province and decentralised capacity building at provincial level, before handover to the World Bank. Prevention of Sexual Exploitation and Abuse (PSEA) as well as Gender-Based Violence (GBV) were mainstreamed into the SCT programme. The programme supported the drafting and finalisation of Statutory Instruments (SIs) on Health, Education, Employment, Accessibility, and Information in order to further promote and protect the rights of persons with disabilities. The Ministry of Community Development and Social Services (MCDSS) established the “TRANSFORM Task Team”, dedicated to the identification of key capacity building needs and the roll-out of the most relevant Transform training modules for officials at various levels. Together with the Task Team, work on the development of a Leadership and Change Management Training and Coaching Package for senior government officials was initiated. Supporting the establishment of a communications cluster responsible for the implementation of a national-level social protection communication and advocacy, with membership across 11 ministries in addition to Civil Society Organisations(CSOs) and media representatives. In partnership with the World Bank, the programme began a Public Expenditure Review of the social protection sector and started work on a sustainable financing strategy. The review was complemented by the development of options for sustainable financing of the social protection sector which started in the last quarter of 2020. A Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) was signed between the MCDSS and the Civil Society for Poverty Reduction (CSPR), leading to activities such as the development and dissemination of advocacy messages to raise awareness among service providers and right-holders through radio programmes and media campaigns. The drought response Emerenct Cash Transfers (ECT) that started in 2019 was concluded and overall, 95,889 beneficiaries in 23 districts were supported through vertical expansion. The covid-19 ECT programme was supported by the programme in 19 districts, and 104,482 beneficiaries (of whom 85,261 are beneficiaries under the vertical expansion, and 19,221 under the horizontal expansion) have been paid by 15 May, 2021. Fourteen districts implemented both vertical and horizontal expansions; an additional five districts implemented the vertical expansion only. A total of 63,560 phones were distributed by 15 May 2021 to beneficiaries to facilitate innovative payment mechanisms through Mobile Network Operators (MNOs) and support the communication with beneficiaries. All 19 districts were supported with nutrition messaging and messaging on health and hygiene, through phone messages, print materials and community sensitisation.
